paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade by creating an interferon-rich inflammatory state?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Combination Efficacy Cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice receiving the combined treatment of intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 checkpoint blockade to assess efficacy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Control Cohorts
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice used for matched controls, including vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle groups.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human Retrospective Metastatic Cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic cancer patients receiving ICI treatment, divided into vaccinated (43 patients) and unvaccinated (87 patients) subgroups based on prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
